review.title: Fuzzy Clustering Data Given in the Ordinal Scale
review.abstract: A fuzzy clustering algorithm for multidimensional data is proposed in this article. The data is described by vectors whose components are linguistic variables defined in an ordinal scale. The obtained results confirm the efficiency of the proposed approach.

metadata.title: Fuzzy Clustering Data Given in the Ordinal Scale

sections.heading: II. THE INITIAL DATA FUZZIFICATION
sections.text: A fuzcification process for a ranking of linguistic variables can be considered on the basis of an example of the one-dimensional sample (1), (2),..., () x x x N, where each observation () x k can be attributed to one of the j ranks, 1,2,..., j m. Let the value () x k (corresponding to the j-th rank) be seen in the sample jN times. Then a relative frequency of occurrence of the j-th rank can be introduced both jN fN and cumulative frequencies 11 2 fF, 112j l F f, 2.3,..., j m, while of course there is a condition 1 1mi i f. Based on these cumulative frequencies, membership functions' j jN fN and cumulative frequencies () jN f (Fig.1) influence 11 2 fF, 112j yl F f f f f f f f f f f f f,..., 2.3,... j, while a cumulative jn fN and cumulative frequency (j.1) can be formed simultaneously with these membership functions.

sections.heading: III. A FUZZY CLUSTERING METHOD FOR ORDINAL DATA
sections.text: Since we perform a multi-dimensional data sample of observations (vectors) for rank 4, the fuzzification procedure will be performed in each coordinate of the n-dimensional feature space similar to the previous example. () Then the functions of membership in this procedure will be shaped as they are shown in a two-dimensional case (Fig.3). sections.heading: IV. EXPERIMENTS
sections.text: In order to verify the efficiency of the proposed method, we have collected data on the academic performance of students at a faculty of the Kharkiv National University of Radio Electronics. One data set contains student grades in 6 subjects for 135 subjects. Statistical analyses showed that a hypothesis for each variable (subject) about the normal distribution of estimates has not been confirmed (Fig.5).Fig.6. A histogram of grade distribution for six subjects (case 1) Fig.7. Membership works with cuts for 6 subjects (case 2) Fig.8. Membership works with cuts for 6 subjects (case 3) Fig.9. Membership works with cuts for 6 subjects (case 1) Fig.10 Membership works with cuts for the subjects (case 2) Fig.11 Membership works with cuts for the subjects (case 3) Fig.9.

referenceMentions.context: INTRODUCTION That’s a very common situation for sociological, medical and educational tasks when initial data is given not in a numeric scale but rather in a rank (ordinal) scale [1-5].

The simplest approach for solving these clustering problems on an ordinal scale is based on replacement of linguistic variables with their ranks but this method is incorrect in most cases because it assumes equal distances between neighboring numerical ranks [6-12].
